(2)–(6). f “(St)” indicates the results after entropy correction. Why could the CrOx/SiO2 and VOx/SiO2 catalysts show so different behaviors in ethylene polymerization? A theoretical approach Shiyang Wang Writing - original draft Boping Liu Conceptualization Supervision Writing - review & editing * Yulong Jin Methodology Writing - original draft Supervision * Key Laboratory for Biomaterials and Energy of Ministry of Education, College of Materials and Energy, South China Agricultural University, Guangzhou 510630, People’s Republic of China Key Laboratory for Biomaterials and Energy of Ministry of Education College of Materials and Energy South China Agricultural University Guangzhou 510630 People’s Republic of China Key Laboratory for Biomaterials and Energy of Ministry of Education, College of Materials and Energy, South China Agricultural University, Guangzhou 510630, People’s Republic of China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract Phillips catalyst (CrOx/SiO2) is one of the most famous industrial catalysts for ethylene polymerization, while VOx/SiO2 catalyst is a promising catalyst capable of making UHMWPE, which was recently developed in our group. These two catalysts were known to show completely deferent behaviors in ethylene polymerization in terms of activity, H2 response and copolymerization ability. However, a molecular insight into the mechanism is not well understood. Herein, a theoretical comparison between them via the propagation through insertion and termination through chain transfer reaction pathways is performed. The results show the transition states for olefins (ethylene, 1-butene and 1-hexene) insertion are energetically more stable in VOx/SiO2. However, the binding energies of the olefins by VOx/SiO2 is obviously lower, which results in the insertion barriers for VOx/SiO2 about 2–3 kcal mol−1 higher than those for CrOx/SiO2. As to the termination, CrOx/SiO2 is more probably to terminate via the BHE (β-H elimination to Cr center) pathway, which generally has lower barriers than those for BHT (β-H elimination to monomer) in the VOx/SiO2 system. Meanwhile, VOx/SiO2 is superior to CrOx/SiO2 in hydrogenolysis, because it is more accessible by the H2, and the reaction barrier is also much lower. The energy gap between the barriers for propagation and termination is generally smaller for CrOx/SiO2, implying its tendency to produce lower MW PE when compared with VOx/SiO2. Furthermore, for CrOx/SiO2, the insertion barriers between C2H4 and α-olefin are bigger and the promotion effect of the incorporated α-olefins on termination is more obvious, which might account for the lower incorporation efficiency for comonomer by CrOx/SiO2, despite of its lower insertion barriers. Keywords Phillips catalyst Vanadium-oxide-based catalyst Ethylene polymerization Density functional theory 1 Introduction Phillips catalyst, consisting of CrOx/SiO2, was one of the first to be commercialized for low pressure production of polyethylene (PE). Though nearly 70 years had passed since its discovery, this catalyst still accounts for almost half of the market for high-density polyethylene (HDPE), primarily due to its competence in producing HDPE products with distinct properties like broad molecular weight distribution (MWD), in-situ generated long chain branch, and so forth. Additionally, Phillips catalyst is also cost-competitive owing to its simple preparation procedures by the impregnation of Cr sources on silica and subsequent high temperature calcination under dehydrated and O2 containing atmosphere [1,2]. In addition to CrOx/SiO2, the vanadium-oxide-based catalyst VOx/SiO2, which could be prepared with the similar way as that for Phillips catalyst, was also found to be active for ethylene polymerization. On the other hand, VOx/SiO2 also presents peculiar catalytic behaviors owned by typical V-based Ziegler-Natta catalysts such as VOCl3 and VCl4 [3]. For instance, VOx/SiO2 is apt to produce PEs with molecular weight (MW) as high as millions [4]. Its efficiency for comonomer incorporation is also excellent. Furthermore, VOx/SiO2 is sensitive to H2, which means the MW of the produced PEs would decrease obviously with relatively low partial pressure of H2 [5]. However, the activity of VOx/SiO2 for olefin polymerization is low and failed to be applied in industry alone. Instead, it is used as promoter for other catalysts [6,7]. Recently, our group also synthesized a series of bimetallic catalysts by co-immobilizing VOx together with others catalysts precursors such as CrOx or silyl-chromate on silica-based supports. Bimodal PEs with reverse short chain branch distribution could be synthesized in one pot with these catalysts, if catalyst composition and reaction conditions were properly regulated [6,8–10]. More recently, we devoted great effort to enhance the efficiency of VOx/SiO2 through the modification of support and activator ingredients, hence, its activity could reach as high as 5 × 103 kg PE mol−1 V [4,11]. As mentioned above, CrOx/SiO2 is an important industrial PE catalyst, while VOx/SiO2 is a newly developed catalyst with potential practicality. For both catalysts, the preparation procedures are almost the same, and their active sites are all anchored on silica surface by SiOM (M = Cr or V) bonds. However, their catalytic behaviors and PE products are obviously different. In comparison to VOx/SiO2, CrOx/SiO2 exhibits much higher activity towards C2H4 polymerization, but its copolymerization efficiency and H2 sensitivity are inferior to the former one, and the MW of its PE products is relatively lower than that synthesized by VOx/SiO2. To give a molecular insight into the underlying mechanism, which is not well understood up to now, we tried to take full advantages of computational method and make a comparative theoretical study on both CrOx/SiO2 and VOx/SiO2 catalysts. 2 Computational methods and models 2.1 Computational models In our calculations, a six-membered siloxane ring was used to model silica support, as it was found to be the most abundant and stable ring size in amorphous silica [12,13]. Demmelmaier et al. also found the most active species on Phillips catalyst are those supported by the strained siloxane rings with 6∼8 Si-O units [14]. The catalyst clusters were obtained by replacing one of the Si atoms with Cr or V. Such cluster models are simple but found be able to reveal the fundamental characteristics of both catalysts. Therefore, it is widely used to investigate the catalytic behaviors of CrOx/SiO2 and VOx/SiO2 in olefin polymerization [15–18]. On the other hand, we also ran calculations on models with bigger silica support derived from the β-cristobalite structure. It generally indicates the relative energies of the active species are similar for the two types of clusters (see Fig. S1 and S2). In addition, as the loading amount of Cr or V in these catalysts is often less than 1 wt %, and the specific surface area of the silica support is usually high, thus highly dispersed Cr or V species are immobilized on the surface. Hence, models with multinuclear were not considered herein. Up to now, there is still a controversy over the virtual active valence of CrOx/SiO2 and VOx/SiO2 for ethylene polymerization [19–21]. However, Cr(III) species were mostly verified to be the active centers in several recent works [21–24]. While V(III) species were also often detected to be the active centers for V-based Ziegler-Natta catalyst as well [25,26]. Jin et al. found that V(III) was the most possible active species for VOx/SiO2 in ethylene polymerization, as the steric hindrance of V(IV) and V(V) species was very large, while the complexation between C2H4 and V(II) species was too strong, which would boost up the overall insertion barrier greatly [16]. On the other hand, though chain initiation mechanism is a very important subject for Phillips catalyst, it is still difficult to reach a consensus [19,27]. Moreover, alkylation agents such as triethyl-aluminum (TEA) are often added for impurity scavenging and the activation of both CrOx/SiO2 and VOx/SiO2 in many works [4,11,28]. Consequently, ethylated Cr(III) and V(III) models shown in Fig. 1 were proposed as the active species for CrOx/SiO2 and VOx/SiO2, respectively. 2.2 Computational methods All calculations were carried out with the Gaussian 09 E.01 package [29]. The structures of reactants, resultants, as well as the transition states were optimized using the long-range corrected hybrid density functional ωB97X-D functional [30] in combination with the double-zeta basis-set def2-SVP [31,32]. The TSN method (keywords: opt = TS) was used to search the transition states, in which an initial structure was built up and computed with the Berny algorithm [33]. The default convergence criteria in Gaussian 09 were executed for all the calculations. The single point energy was calculated with the same functional as for structure optimization but with the more accurate triple-zeta basis-set def2-TZVPP [31,32]. We also calculated the single point energies of several optimized structures for C2H4 insertion by ωB97X-D3/def2-TZVPP with the ORCA 4.1 program, [34] since it is believed that the DFT-D3(BJ) dispersion corrections integrated in ωB97X-D3 are endowed with improved accuracy in comparison to the DFT-D2(BJ) included by ωB97X-D [35]. It is found the electronic energies calculated by ωB97X-D3/def2-TZVPP are consistently lower, but the relative energies for the species in C2H4 insertion are comparable for both theoretical levels (see Table S1 in Supporting information). This computational protocol was applied for both CrOx/SiO2 and VOx/SiO2, which had been demonstrated reasonable previously [16] Harmonic frequencies were computed to verify that the local minimum for reactants and products had no imaginary frequencies and the 1st order saddle points for each transition state had only one imaginary frequency. At the same time, the Gibbs energy corrections were calculated at T =298 K and P =1 atm. To ensure that the reactant and the product are correctly connected by the located transition state, the intrinsic reaction coordinate (IRC) method was applied afterwards [36,37]. We predict the reaction pathways through the Gibbs free energies which were obtained by adding the single point energies to the Gibbs energy corrections. Jin et al. and Floryan et al. had summarized the relationship between spin multiplicity and the stability of V(III) and Cr(III) active species, finding the high-spin state (i.e., quartet for Cr(III) and triplet for V(III)) was always more stable than the low-spin ones [16,21]. Therefore, all the calculations were also carried out with high-spin states herein. The Nature Bond Orbital analysis (NBO) was performed by the integrated NBO program in Gaussian, and the applied computational protocol was the same to that for the single point energy calculation [38]. The electrostatic potential (ESP) defined on the molecular Van der Waals surface, as well as the electron density difference maps were graphed by the combination of Multiwfn 3.9 and VMD 1.9.1 programs [39,40]. The electron density difference maps were produced by the following equation: Δρ = ρAB-ρA-ρB, where ρAB is the electron density of the complex consisted by A and B, ρA and ρB imply the electron density of A and B alone, but have their structures kept the same as in the complex, and Δρ is the obtained electron density difference. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Chain propagation through insertion We firstly performed a calculation on chain propagation. It proceeds through the first insertion of a C2H4 or an α-olefin (1-butene and 1-hexene) and a subsequent insertion of another C2H4. The Cossee-Alrman mechanism, which is often believed to be applicable to olefin coordination polymerization, is used to describe the chain propagation process [41]. Firstly, the free olefins would complex with the catalysts through the vacant coordination site of the metal centers. Then, the transition state with a geometry of four-membered ring, which is consisted by the MC bond in M-alkyl and CC bond in olefins, would come into being. Finally, the product would be obtained by accomplishing the insertion of the alkylene carbons into the MC bond. The vacant coordination site would be regenerated and ready for the insertion of the next olefin (see Scheme 1 ). For the incorporation of α-olefin, a regioselectivity should be considered. It is found the 1,2-insertion is more or less energetically preferred than the 2,1-insertion (see Fig. S1 in the Supporting Information). It might be mainly due to the steric effect between the incoming α-olefin and the catalyst framework, which is commonly met in the coordination polymerization of α-olefin [42–45]. Therefore, in the following discussion, the results only for the 1,2-insertion are taken into account if α-olefin is involved. We primarily investigate the insertion of the first olefin, as shown in Fig. 2 (a), the coordination of a C2H4 to CrOx/SiO2 is exothermic and a heat of 2.2 kcal mol−1 would be released. Afterwards, an energy barrier of 14.9 kcal mol−1 has to be overcome to realize the C2H4 insertion. The obtained product has an energy about 14 kcal mol−1 lower than the free system (bare catalyst + one C2H4), which indicates a strong exothermic process for C2H4 insertion. It is coincident with the results of Sun et al. and Fong et al., who also investigated the Phillips catalyst for C2H4 polymerization with similar cluster models [46,47], They declared modest binding energies of −1–2 kcal mol−1 for C2H4, a insertion barrier about 17 kcal mol−1, and a reaction enthalpy about−10–−12 kcal mol−1. On the other hand, Floryan et al. [21] reported the binding energies for a C2H4 molecule were about −8–5 kcal mol−1, while the insertion barriers were in the range of 0.9–5.5 kcal mol−1. Such a discrepancy might result from the amorphous periodic models of silica adopted by them, since it was able to describe the variation of the silica surface more accurately and allow to build up active sites with diversified coordination conditions [48]. In addition, the differences in computational details, such as program package and functionals, should also be taken into account. With respect to VOx/SiO2, it is distinct that the coordination of C2H4 is much stronger, that is, a binding energy lower than −7 kcal mol−1 could be seen. This impedes the subsequent insertion obviously and results in an energy barrier higher than 18 kcal mol−1. However, it is intriguing to find that more stable transition state of C2H4 insertion could even be formed on VOx/SiO2 in comparison to that of CrOx/SiO2. As shown in Fig. 3 , we look into several key bonds involved in the insertion process. It is found that the length of V-C1 is about 0.05 Å longer than Cr-C2 for the bare models. After the coordination of C2H4, the length of M-C1 is kept nearly constant, but for VOx/SiO2, the M-C3 and C1-C4 are respectively 0.13 and 0.05 Å shorter, and the double bond of C3=C4 in C2H4 is 0.01 Å longer. It means the C2H4 could be more strongly complexed with VOx/SiO2, which is also in compatible with its much lower binding energy with C2H4. During the formation of the transition states, the distance of M-C3 is similar on both catalysts, but the C1-C4 decreases to 2.14 Å and the C3=C4 elongates to 1.42 Å for VOx/SiO2, which are 0.08 Å shorter and 0.02 longer Å than those values observed for CrOx/SiO2, respectively. Furthermore, the M-C1 bond stretches from 2.04 to 2.17 Å in VOx/SiO2, but from 2.00 to 2.07 Å in CrOx/SiO2. It indicates that, during the insertion of C2H4, both the catalyst and the C2H4 is more severely activated in the VOx/SiO2 system. This is also in accordance with its lower energy in transition state in comparison to that for CrOx/SiO2. For the cases in which 1-butene or 1-hexene is firstly inserted (see Fig. 2 (b) and (c)), since the metal centers are sterically open, the binding energies for 1-butene and 1-hexene are almost the same to those for C2H4, despite of the longer chain length of the comonomers. However, the transition states for comonomer insertion locate at higher energy level, and hence the overall insertion barriers are all about 2∼3 kcal mol−1 higher than the insertion of C2H4. It is coincident with the lower reactivity ratios of α-olefins than C2H4 in olefin coordination polymerization [49,50]. On the other hand, when compared with CrOx/SiO2, VOx/SiO2 is still much more appealing to the upcoming comonomers. It predominantly renders the insertion barrier about 3 kcal mol−1 higher in VOx/SiO2 than CrOx/SiO2. Regarding to the products for the insertion of the first olefin, the terminal H atoms tend to bite back the metal center. It is more obvious when α-olefins are incorporated. Because the growing chain is relatively longer and more flexible, which facilitates the interactions between the terminal H atoms and the unsaturated metal centers (see Fig. S2 in the Supporting Information). Consequently, the complexing of the awaiting C2H4 becomes a bit difficult, which could be reflected by the less negative binding energies. It frees the binding C2H4 more or less and enhances the energy level of the starting point for the subsequent insertion. Nevertheless, the energies of the transition states for insertion increase a bit as well. Therefore, the overall insertion barriers for the second olefin (C2H4) are kept comparable to those for the firstly incorporated C2H4, which ensures the sustainability of the propagation. The calculated energies above clearly demonstrate that VOx/SiO2 has slower incorporation rate of 1-butene and 1-hexene than CrOx/SiO2. More importantly, just like in the case of C2H4 insertion, it is still the relatively stronger binding of the α-olefin that enlarges the insertion barriers. Similarly, it could be verified by the structural characters of the species formed during the insertion process as well (see Fig. S3 in the Supporting Information). Nevertheless, it is worthy to note that the differences in the insertion barriers between C2H4 and α-olefin (for both primary and secondary propagations, see Fig. 2 and Fig. S1) are bigger for CrOx/SiO2. It indicates its higher reactivity ratio for C2H4, which could partially illustrate that CrOx/SiO2 possesses less incorporation efficiency for comonomers when compared with VOx/SiO2. On the hand other, given the analogous steric hindrance around the metal centers for both catalyst models, we also try to illustrate their catalytic behaviors through the electronic properties of the catalysts. Firstly, we analyze the NBO charges of the metal centers in M-3X (M = Cr or V, X = E, B or H), which are the bare catalysts ready for the coordination with the second C2H4 (see Fig. 4 ). However, it is found these atomic charges are almost the same in all the cases. Afterward, we calculate the electrostatic potential (ESP) distribution on the surface of the catalysts to predict their electrophilic in a more global way (see Fig. 5 ). Normally, the higher ESP a region of the catalyst surface has, the more nucleus charges it owns, which indicates a higher electrophilic of this region [51]. With respect to CrOx/SiO2, we can see positive ESP could be observed distinctly at the top of the Cr center, but it is kept almost neutral at the lower region. As to VOx/SiO2, it is found the ESP is distributed in a more homogeneous way, and highly positive ESP could be clearly observed around the V center, which would facilitate its electrophilic attack to the upcoming olefins. Therefore, the binding energies of olefins by VOx/SiO2 is much lower. With regard to the transition states, we analyze the frontier molecular orbitals of the reaction system, which includes the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) of the catalysts and the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) of the olefins. Because the reception of π electrons by the LUMO of the catalysts from the HOMO of the olefins is one of the key steps to accomplish the insertion process [52]. As shown in Fig. 4, the energy gaps between the LUMO of the catalysts and the HOMO of the olefins in VOx/SiO2 are all about 0.2 eV (4.6 kcal) lower than those in CrOx/SiO2. It implies the more readily electronic interactions between these two orbitals [53–55]. This could be further verified by the electron difference maps of the species in the transition states for the insertion of the first olefin. As shown in Fig. 6 , the electronic interactions mainly occur between the metal centers and one of the alkylene carbons of olefins (C3). The lobe patterns suggest that the π electrons of the p orbitals belong to C3 would migrate to the d orbitals of the metal centers. However, when put CrOx/SiO2 and VOx/SiO2 into comparison, it could be found the increasement of electron density between V and C3 is more obvious, and the direct contact between d orbitals of V and p orbitals of C3 could be seen clearly. In addition, when take close look into the region between M and the alkyl carbon (C1), the decrement of electron density could be observed for V-C1, but it could be hardly seen for Cr-C1. This implies the more obvious bond weakening for V-C1, and the olefins could be more easily inserted as a result. Generally, it is in agreement with the lower energies of the transition states for olefin insertion in VOx/SiO2. For the insertion of the second olefin, similar electronic interaction between the catalysts and olefins could be observed as well (see Fig. S4 in the Supporting Information). 3.2 Chain termination through chain transfer After the insertion of the first olefin, chain termination process is investigated as well (see Scheme 2 ). For CrOx/SiO2, the experimental results showed that the number average molecular weight (Mn) of its PE product would increase with the improved C2H4 partial pressure, but the actual response was between zero and first order [1,56]. With regard to VOx/SiO2, Liu et al. found both the Mn and Mw of the PE synthesized by this catalyst system could be hardly affected by the varied C2H4 concentrations [57]. As a consequence, for the former system, two primary reaction pathways are considered, one is the β-H transfer to the upcoming C2H4 (BHT), the other is the β-H transfer to the metal centers (i.e., β-H elimination, BHE). For the latter one, we mainly focus on the BHT process, while the BHE process is only investigated and briefly discussed in the Supporting Information (see Fig. S8). Besides, the chain termination goes on through hydrogenolysis is also investigated by the introduction of a H2 molecule. For the BHT process, as shown in Scheme 2 (A), the C2H4 monomer would coordinate with the metal centers in advance. Since the β-H of M-alkyl tends to has an agostic interaction with the metal centers and becomes electronically deficient, it is apt to be attacked by the electronically abundant C2H4 and form the transition state of a six-membered ring [58]. Subsequently, the ring would decompose to produce a polymer chain with a terminal vinyl and an ethylated active site. The energy profiles show that the binding energies of the C2H4 by VOx/SiO2 are also much lower than those for the CrOx/SiO2 system (see Fig. 7 ). According to the structural characters of the species in Fig. 7 (a), we can see the distance of M-C3 is about 0.3 Å closer in the case of VOx/SiO2, which verifies its tighter binding to C2H4 (see Fig. 8 ). Meanwhile, it is found the agostic interaction between Cr and β-H of the polymer chain is stronger, as the distance of Cr-H1 is obvious shorter. It indicates the possibility of CrOx/SiO2 to work on the BHE pathway [59]. As a result, its accessibility by C2H4 also decreases more or less. In the transition states, it is distinct that the energies are 6∼8 kcal mol−1 higher in CrOx/SiO2 than VOx/SiO2, and the overall transfer barriers are also 1–2 kcal mol−1 higher in the former system. With regard to CrOx/SiO2, Fong et al. [47] also calculated the BHT pathway and reported a comparable reaction barrier (23.7 kcal mol−1) to ours (24.0 kcal mol−1). While Floryan et al. [21] and Gierada et al. [60] gave an overall barrier of 21.4 kcal mol−1and 25.8 kcal mol−1, respectively, which are possibly due to the different silica models (period surface or β-cristobalite-like cluster) used by them. Furthermore, the terminal alkenyl of the growth chain on their Cr(III) sites would also affect the BHT process more or less. The structural features of the species in transition states show that the C2H4 is more highly activated by VOx/SiO2, since the monomer is stretched longer and readily to abstract the β-H lying closer to it. Whereas the MC1 bond is actually weakened to a higher degree in CrOx/SiO2. Therefore, we further make an analysis on the electronic interaction between the catalyst and olefins in transition states (see Fig. 9 ). For VOx/SiO2, it is obvious that more π electrons of the olefins would migrate to the region between M and C3, as well as that between the β-H and C4. It clearly indicates the higher tendency of the C2H4 to abstract the β-H and bond with the metal centers in VOx/SiO2, therefore, the BHT proceeds more easily. Pertaining to the BHE process for CrOx/SiO2, the energy profiles as shown in Fig. 10 demonstrate that the barriers for BHE are almost the same to those for the insertion process. Therefore, only low MW PE could be produced by this kind of active site. Fong et al. also reported similar low barriers for BHE (about 2 kcal mol−1 higher than that for insertion) over CrOx/SiO2, and the predicted MW for the synthesized PE was about 100–3000 g mol−1. They attributed it to the small error in DFT calculations [47]. In addition, the variability of chain transfer process is distinct as well [61]. Besides, it is also suggested this unconformity might originate from the overestimations on the entropy effect (particularly contributed from the translational component) for those unimolecular steps, in which the BHE process was covered as well [62,63]. As a result, we further correct the BHE process with the validated computational protocol for entropy correction proposed by Falivene et al. [62] (see Eq. 1), and the results are given in Fig. 10 for comparison. It could be seen that the corrected translational entropies would promote the barriers about 2∼2.2 kcal mol−1 for BHE. It makes the chain propagation be more competitive, and ensures the smooth going of the polymerization process, but the barrier differences between insertion and BHE are still kept low (about 2–4 kcal mol−1). Herein, it should be noted that Phillips catalyst is actually famous for its multisite characters, which are responsible for polymerizing C2H4 into chains with MW from thousands to millions. In this regard, it indicates the model built in this work is more likely to reflect the active species on Phillips catalyst for the synthesis of low MW PEs. The correction item represented by △ S cond,exp solvent - △ S cond solvent is obtained by subtracting the solvent condensation entropies measured experimentally ( △ S cond,exp solvent ) with that calculated by the classical Sackur-Tetrode equation ( △ S cond solvent ) [64]. Herein, we followed Falivene et al. and did the correction with toluene as solvent, which is widely used in olefin polymerization, that is, △ S cond,exp solvent = -50.3 J· K - 1 · mol - 1 . Concerning the hydrogenolysis process (see Fig. 11 ), it is found the binding of a H2 molecule is endothermic for both CrOx/SiO2 and VOx/SiO2, though it is a bit less for the latter one. It might be due to the poorer donor role of H2 when compared with C2H4 [65]. The transition state formed with VOx/SiO2 is about 16 kcal mol−1, but that with CrOx/SiO2 is more than 21 kcal mol−1, which is even comparable to the reaction barriers for BHT. It is compatible with the experimental observations that CrOx/SiO2 is insensitive to H2 in the modulation of the MW of PE products, but the opposite phenomenon is observed for VOx/SiO2. As shown in Fig. 12 , the electron density difference maps indicate that the complexed H2 would donate relatively more electrons to V center, as reflected by the distinct red lobes between them, but it is unobvious for CrOx/SiO2. In the transition states, the electron density increasement between H2 and Cr or V is similar, but its decrement between V and C is more dominant. Hence, the lower energy of the transition state for hydrogenolysis met in VOx/SiO2 is possibly due to its more highly weakened VC bond. 3.3 Chain propagation vs chain termination It is the relative energy gap between the barriers of chain propagation and termination that primarily determines the MW of the PE products. Therefore, we predict the most probable MW of PEs on the basis of the Eqs. (2) to (6): [66] For CrOx/SiO2, the reaction barriers for termination (ΔGt ‡) are based on the BHE pathway, since this process before and after the entropy correction are both more competent than the BHT. For VOx/SiO2, only the BHT process is considered. Pertaining to hydrogenolysis, since the partial pressure and solubility of H2 might also have great effect on its reaction kinetics, we think it is very complicated and prefer not to discuss herein. (2) MW 28.06 = P n ¯ = k p k tBHT (3) MW 28.06 = P n ¯ = C C2H4 k p k tBHE (4) k x = RT N A h exp ( -ΔG x ‡ RT ) (5) MW 28.06 =exp ( ΔG t BHT ‡ - ΔG p ‡ RT ) (6) MW 28.06 = C C2H4 exp ( ΔG tBHE ‡ - ΔG p ‡ RT ) Where P n ¯ is the most probable polymerization degree, k p , k t BHT and k t BHE are respectively the rate constants for chain propagation, BHT and BHE processes, R is the gas constant, T is the reaction temperature in K, ΔG p ‡ , ΔG t BHT ‡ and ΔG tBHE ‡ indicate the reaction barriers in J mol−1 for chain propagation, BHT and BHE, respectively. x = p, tBHT or tBHE in Eq. (4). C C 2 H 4 is the C2H4 concentration in mol·L−1. In this work, CC2H4 = 0.12 mol·L−1 is used, which is calculated from the experimental solubility of C2H4 in toluene (1 atm, 298 K) [67]. The results listed in Table 1 shows that the MW of the PEs produced by VOx/SiO2 is in the range of 3–6 × 104 g mol−1, while it is obviously lower for CrOx/SiO2 (MW = 5.6 × 103 g mol−1), even though after the entropy correction for BHE. It is in agreement with the experimental observation that VOx/SiO2 is more competent in producing high MW PEs in comparison to CrOx/SiO2. Besides, as to CrOx/SiO2, it is found the MW of the PEs predicted for Cr-3B and Cr-3H is obviously lower than that for Cr-3E. It is probably due to the previously inserted 1-butene and 1-hexene for Cr-3B and Cr-3H, respectively, since the β-H is more active when bonded with a tertiary carbon.50 With respect to VOx/SiO2, such a difference is small. It is likely to originate from the BHT pathway working in this catalyst system, since the tightly complexed C2H4 would impede the close contact of the β-H with the V center, and make the chain transfer process less sensitive to the chemical properties of the β-H (see Fig. 5) [68,69]. Meanwhile, the more obvious promotion effect brought by the inserted α-olefins for termination in the CrOx/SiO2 system might also partially account for its lower efficiency for comonomer incorporation in comparison to VOx/SiO2, despite of its lower insertion barriers for 1-butene and 1-hexene. This is also in accordance with the experimental observation that the MW for the PE produced by Phillips catalyst tends to be suppressed obviously by the increased concentration of α-olefins [1]. On the other hand, it is worth to note that some deviations about the quantitative description of the MW are exist, because of the inevitable computational errors in DFT calculations [47]. Furthermore, the termination process is believed to pose a greater challenge than the insertion one for olefin coordination polymerization [61,70]. Moreover, the non-equivalence between the cluster models and the real catalyst surfaces would also result in a discrepancy. Since the Phillips catalyst is distinguished for its diversity in active sites, which are different in coordination conditions and enabled to produce PE chains with various lengths. 4 Conclusions A theoretical comparison was performed for both VOx/SiO2 and CrOx/SiO2, through the pathways of chain propagation and termination, to shed light on their distinct catalytic behaviors in ethylene polymerization. That is, CrOx/SiO2 show obviously higher activity, while VOx/SiO2 has an advantage on producing high MW PE and incorporating α-olefin more efficiently. In addition, the latter one also presents higher sensitivity towards hydrogenolysis. The results show that more stable transition states for olefins (ethylene, 1-butene and 1-hexene) insertion could actually be observed for VOx/SiO2. It might be partially attributed to the smaller energy gap between the LUMO of VOx/SiO2 and the HOMO of the olefins, which might facilitate the electronic interaction between them. It is further verified by the electronic analysis of CrOx/SiO2 and VOx/SiO2, which shows that more π electrons of olefins are apt to migrate to the V centers and the V-alkyl bond would also be more strongly weakened. However, the binding energies of the olefins by VOx/SiO2 is obviously lower, because of the more positive electrostatic potential (ESP) around the V centers. It results in the insertion barriers for VOx/SiO2 about 2∼3 kcal mol−1 higher than those for CrOx/SiO2, which accounts for the higher activity of the latter one. With respect to chain termination, according to the experimental observations, two primary pathways including the BHE (β-H elimination to metal) and BHT (β-H transfer to monomer) are considered for CrOx/SiO2, while only the latter one is taken into account for VOx/SiO2. It is found that the reaction barriers for CrOx/SiO2 in BHE (15.5∼18.5 kcal mol−1) are so low that the proceeding of the polymerization is difficult. This contradiction is avoided by the correction of its translational entropies. With respect to the BHT pathway, the corresponding barriers (22–23 kcal mol−1) are relatively higher for both CrOx/SiO2 and VOx/SiO2. Regarding to hydrogenolysis, the complexation of a H2 molecule is moderately and highly endothermic for VOx/SiO2 and CrOx/SiO2, respectively, since H2 is a poorer electron donator when compared with C2H4. In addition, the overall barrier is 7 kcal mol−1 higher for CrOx/SiO2 due to its less stable transition state. The MW of the produced PE is predicted on the basis of the energy gaps between the barriers for propagation and termination. It is found that the MW of the PE produced by CrOx/SiO2 (≤5.6 × 103 g mol-1) is lower than that by VOx/SiO2 (3–6 × 104 g mol−1), which is qualitatively compatible with the experimental observation. Meanwhile, the insertion barriers between C2H4 and α-olefin are bigger for CrOx/SiO2, and the promotion effect of the incorporated α-olefins on termination is also more obvious for this catalyst system, which might account for its lower incorporation efficiency for comonomer in comparison to VOx/SiO2, despite of its lower insertion barriers. coredata.dc:description: Phillips catalyst (CrOx/SiO2) is one of the most famous industrial catalysts for ethylene polymerization, while VOx/SiO2 catalyst is a promising catalyst capable of making UHMWPE, which was recently developed in our group. These two catalysts were known to show completely deferent behaviors in ethylene polymerization in terms of activity, H2 response and copolymerization ability. However, a molecular insight into the mechanism is not well understood. Herein, a theoretical comparison between them via the propagation through insertion and termination through chain transfer reaction pathways is performed. The results show the transition states for olefins (ethylene, 1-butene and 1-hexene) insertion are energetically more stable in VOx/SiO2. However, the binding energies of the olefins by VOx/SiO2 is obviously lower, which results in the insertion barriers for VOx/SiO2 about 2–3 kcal mol−1 higher than those for CrOx/SiO2. As to the termination, CrOx/SiO2 is more probably to terminate via the BHE (β-H elimination to Cr center) pathway, which generally has lower barriers than those for BHT (β-H elimination to monomer) in the VOx/SiO2 system. Meanwhile, VOx/SiO2 is superior to CrOx/SiO2 in hydrogenolysis, because it is more accessible by the H2, and the reaction barrier is also much lower. The energy gap between the barriers for propagation and termination is generally smaller for CrOx/SiO2, implying its tendency to produce lower MW PE when compared with VOx/SiO2. Furthermore, for CrOx/SiO2, the insertion barriers between C2H4 and α-olefin are bigger and the promotion effect of the incorporated α-olefins on termination is more obvious, which might account for the lower incorporation efficiency for comonomer by CrOx/SiO2, despite of its lower insertion barriers.
coredata.dc:title: Why could the CrOx/SiO2 and VOx/SiO2 catalysts show so different behaviors in ethylene polymerization? A theoretical approach
